misconceptions.name: No random number generation and no user-driven guesses
misconceptions.description: The student hard-codes both the guess and the answer as 5 instead of generating a random secret number between 1 and 100 and reading guesses from the user.
misconceptions.student_belief: Setting guess and answer to fixed values in the code is sufficient for implementing the guessing game.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must create a Random object, generate a secret number between 1 and 100, and then read guesses from the user via Scanner rather than hard-coding values.
symptoms: No Random object or nextInt call anywhere in the program
Both guess and answer are initialized to the literal 5
Scanner is only used for the road-trip cost input, not for guesses
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion about how to integrate randomness and user input into a loop-based game, or reuse of code from an unrelated problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the hard-coded guess and answer with: Random rand = new Random(); int answer = rand.nextInt(100) + 1; and read each guess from input using Scanner.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code clearly sets both guess and answer to 5 and never uses Random or Scanner for guesses.

evidence.note: Both guess and answer are hard-coded to 5; there is no Random object or random number generation for the secret value.

misconceptions.name: Missing loop for repeated guessing
misconceptions.description: The program checks the guess only once and has no loop to allow the user to keep guessing until they are correct.
misconceptions.student_belief: A single if-statement comparing guess and answer is enough to implement the guessing behavior.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The guessing game must be wrapped in a while or do-while loop so that the user can make multiple guesses until the correct number is found.
symptoms: No while or do-while loop around the guessing logic
Only one comparison between guess and answer is performed
misconceptions.root_cause: Incomplete understanding of how to use loops to repeat user interaction until a condition is met.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Enclose the input and comparison of guess vs answer in a while loop that continues until the guess equals the answer.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The only game-related logic consists of a single if-statement; there are no loop constructs present.

evidence.note: The guessing logic is a single if-statement with no surrounding while/do-while loop.

misconceptions.name: No feedback when guess is too high
misconceptions.description: The program never checks whether the guess is greater than the answer and never prints a "Too high" hint.
misconceptions.student_belief: Only checking whether the guess equals the answer is enough; explicit 'Too high' feedback is not implemented.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For each incorrect guess, if the guess is greater than the secret number, the program should inform the user that the guess is "Too high".
symptoms: No comparison of guess > answer
No print statement containing 'Too high'
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding or overlooking the requirement to provide directional feedback when guesses are incorrect.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add an else-if branch: if (guess > answer) { System.out.println("Too high!"); }.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code only has an equality check and a single output; there is no branch handling the 'too high' case.

evidence.note: The only conditional checks (intended) equality and prints a generic message; there is no branch or message for the 'Too high' case.

misconceptions.name: No feedback when guess is too low
misconceptions.description: The program never checks whether the guess is less than the answer and never prints a "Too low" hint.
misconceptions.student_belief: Only checking equality is sufficient; explicit 'Too low' feedback is not necessary.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For each incorrect guess, if the guess is less than the secret number, the program should inform the user that the guess is "Too low".
symptoms: No comparison of guess < answer
No print statement containing 'Too low'
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to translate the requirement for 'Too low' hints into a separate conditional branch.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add an else-if branch: else if (guess < answer) { System.out.println("Too low!"); }.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is no branch in the code that checks guess < answer or prints any 'Too low' style message.

evidence.note: Only an (intended) equality check is present; missing any separate 'Too low' branch or message.

misconceptions.name: Using assignment instead of equality in if condition
misconceptions.description: The student writes if (guess = answer) instead of using the equality operator ==, which suggests confusion between assignment and comparison and prevents correct termination logic.
misconceptions.student_belief: Using a single equals sign inside an if condition compares two values.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, = assigns a value to a variable, while == compares two values for equality. The condition for correct guess should use guess == answer.
symptoms: if condition uses guess = answer instead of guess == answer
This code does not compile in Java because an int result of assignment cannot be used as a boolean condition
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between mathematical notation and Java operators, or lack of familiarity with Java's equality operator.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the condition to if (guess == answer) and review the difference between assignment (=) and equality (==) in Java.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The misuse of = in the if condition is explicit and matches a common documented misconception.

evidence.note: The if condition uses the assignment operator = where an equality comparison (==) is required.

misconceptions.name: Task Misunderstanding: Submitted code for an unrelated problem
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate road trip cost, which is entirely irrelevant to the requested Number Guessing Game assignment. None of the core requirements (random number generation, guessing loop, or conditional feedback) for Q2 are present.
misconceptions.student_belief: The submitted code addresses the current assignment requirements.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The submitted code must specifically implement a number guessing game, including generating a random number, prompting for user input in a loop, and providing 'too high'/'too low' feedback.
symptoms: Code calculates fuel cost instead of playing a game
Missing user interactions relevant to Q2
Missing Random class utilization
misconceptions.root_cause: Misreading the assignment prompt or submitting an incorrect file.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the requirements for Q2 (Number Guessing Game) and write the appropriate code to fulfill those tasks.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student code clearly calculates fuel cost using variables like 'distance', 'mpg', and 'price', which confirms it is code for a different problem.

evidence.note: The core logic of the submitted program focuses on calculating fuel cost, which is irrelevant to the required Number Guessing Game.

misconceptions.name: Confusion between Assignment (=) and Equality (==) operators
misconceptions.description: The student incorrectly used the assignment operator (`=`) inside an `if` condition when they intended to use the equality comparison operator (`==`). In Java, this assignment expression returns an integer, which cannot be implicitly converted to a boolean condition, causing a compilation error.
misconceptions.student_belief: The single equals sign (`=`) is used to check for equality inside conditional statements, similar to how it might be used in some non-Java languages or pseudocode.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, the single equals sign (`=`) is for assignment. The double equals sign (`==`) is for checking equality, which is required for boolean expressions like those in `if` statements.
symptoms: Compiler error: Incompatible types: int cannot be converted to boolean.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding the fundamental difference between assignment and comparison operations in Java.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Always use `==` when comparing two values for equality in conditional statements.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Direct evidence of `if (guess = answer)` clearly displays the assignment vs. equality error.

evidence.note: The use of `=` where `==` is required for equality comparison.

misconceptions.name: Missing Random Number Generation
misconceptions.description: The student did not implement the required random number generation using the Random class. Instead, they hardcoded the answer as a fixed value (5), which does not meet the specification of generating a random number between 1 and 100.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that a hardcoded constant value can substitute for generating a random number, or they may not have understood the requirement to use the Random class.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must generate a random number between 1 and 100 using: Random rand = new Random(); int answer = rand.nextInt(100) + 1;
symptoms: No Random import or usage
Answer is hardcoded to 5
Game cannot vary between runs
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of the problem requirements or incomplete implementation of the guessing game logic.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Import java.util.Random and use the provided hint to generate a random number before the game loop begins.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code clearly shows a hardcoded answer value with no Random import or usage, making this unambiguous.

evidence.note: Answer is hardcoded to 5 instead of being generated randomly between 1-100.
Only Scanner is imported; Random class is not imported as required.

misconceptions.name: Missing Guessing Loop
misconceptions.description: The student did not implement a loop structure (while or do-while) to allow the user to make multiple guesses. The code only has one comparison and no mechanism for repeated guessing.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student may believe that a single if statement is sufficient to complete the game, or they did not understand the need for a loop to handle multiple attempts.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The game must use a loop (while or do-while) that continues until the user guesses correctly, prompting for input multiple times.
symptoms: No while or do-while loop present
Only one comparison check
Cannot handle multiple guesses
No repeated prompting for user input
misconceptions.root_cause: Incomplete implementation or misunderstanding of the loop requirement for handling repeated user interactions.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Wrap the guess prompt and comparison logic in a while loop that continues until guess == answer.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code clearly lacks any loop structure and only contains a single if statement, making this misconception evident.

evidence.note: Only a single if statement; no loop structure for repeated guessing.

No "Too high!" output

misconceptions.name: Missing Correct Termination Logic and Assignment Operator Misuse
misconceptions.description: The student used the assignment operator (=) instead of the equality comparison operator (==) in the if statement, which assigns rather than compares. Additionally, the game lacks proper termination logic that counts guesses and exits when the correct answer is reached.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that a single = operator in an if condition performs a comparison, similar to comparison operators. They may not understand the distinction between assignment (=) and equality (==).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Use == for comparison in conditional statements: if (guess == answer). The game should terminate only when the user guesses correctly, and the number of guesses should be tracked and displayed.
symptoms: Assignment (=) used instead of comparison (==)
If condition performs assignment rather than comparison
No guess counter
No proper game termination
Message says "They are equal" instead of "Correct!"
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between assignment and comparison operators; incomplete implementation of termination logic.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace = with == in the if condition. Implement a counter to track the number of guesses and display it when the answer is correct. The loop should break when guess == answer.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly shows = instead of == in the if condition, and there is no guess counting or proper termination logic.

evidence.note: Uses assignment operator (=) instead of equality operator (==). Also prints wrong message and lacks guess counting.

misconceptions.name: Using assignment operator instead of equality in condition
misconceptions.description: The student uses the assignment operator '=' inside an if-condition where a boolean comparison is required, indicating confusion between assignment and equality testing in Java.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that 'if (guess = answer)' will check whether guess and answer are equal.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, '=' assigns a value to a variable, while '==' compares two values for equality. If-statements require a boolean expression such as 'guess == answer'.
symptoms: Uses 'if (guess = answer)' instead of 'if (guess == answer)'
Code would not compile: assignment expression of type int is not a boolean
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely transfer from mathematics, where '=' denotes equality, and lack of distinction between assignment and comparison operators in programming.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace 'if (guess = answer)' with 'if (guess == answer)', and review how '=' and '==' are used differently in Java.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence because the incorrect pattern 'if (guess = answer)' appears explicitly in the code and is a common equality-vs-assignment misconception.

evidence.note: The if-condition uses '=' instead of '==', showing confusion between assignment and equality testing.

misconceptions.name: Assignment used in conditional expression (instead of equality comparison)
misconceptions.description: The student used the assignment operator (`=`) inside an `if` condition instead of the equality comparison operator (`==`). This causes a syntax error in Java for boolean conditions (unless the assignment evaluates to a boolean), indicating confusion between assignment and comparison.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that `=` performs comparison in a Java `if` statement, similar to some other programming contexts, or is confused about expression types.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, the equality comparison operator is `==`. The single equals sign (`=`) is the assignment operator, which is not allowed as a conditional expression result (unless the result type is boolean, which is not the case here as it assigns an `int`).
symptoms: Compiler error: Incompatible types: int cannot be converted to boolean
Incorrect logic flow if the code were allowed (always assigns the value)
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between assignment operator (`=`) and equality operator (`==`).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: To check if two values are equal, use the double equals sign (`==`). Remember that the single equals sign (`=`) assigns a value.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Direct presence of the code 'if (guess = answer)' which is a classic syntactic error indicating confusion between = and ==.

evidence.note: The condition uses assignment (=) instead of comparison (==), which is a compile-time error in this context.

misconceptions.name: Assignment operator (=) used instead of comparison operator (==)
misconceptions.description: The student uses the assignment operator (=) inside an if condition instead of the equality comparison operator (==). This causes the condition to perform an assignment rather than evaluate equality, and the result is unpredictable.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that = can be used to test equality in a conditional statement.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, == is the equality comparison operator used in conditionals. The = operator performs assignment and should not be used in if conditions to test equality. The correct syntax is: if (guess == answer).
symptoms: The if condition will always assign the value of answer to guess
The condition will evaluate based on the assigned value, not on equality check
Game logic will not work as intended
misconceptions.root_cause: Common beginner mistake confusing the single = (assignment) with double == (comparison) in conditional statements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace 'if (guess = answer)' with 'if (guess == answer)'. Remember: use == for comparison in conditionals, and = for assignment.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code clearly shows '=' instead of '==' in the if statement, which is unambiguous evidence of this misconception.

evidence.note: The condition uses single = (assignment) instead of == (comparison). This will assign answer to guess rather than test equality.
